title: 104_s1130
content:
The Act titled "Federal Financial Management Improvement Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. The Congress finds that Federal financial management is deficient, with accounting standards not uniformly implemented, costs not fully identified, liabilities not reflected accurately, and the financial condition of the Federal Government not accurately reported. The Congress finds that Federal financial management is deficient, with accounting standards not uniformly implemented, costs not fully identified, liabilities not reflected accurately, and the financial condition of the Federal Government not accurately reported. The report highlights the need for agencies to incorporate accounting standards and reporting objectives established for the Federal Government into their financial management systems to rebuild accountability, credibility, and public confidence. The Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board (FASAB) has been working since October 1990 to develop accounting concepts and standards for the Federal Government. Once implemented, these standards will improve the accuracy and consistency of financial information provided by agencies. The Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board (FASAB) has been developing accounting concepts and standards for the Federal Government since October 1990. The purpose of this Act is to provide cost and financial information to assist Congress and financial managers in evaluating the performance of Federal programs. Developing financial management systems to support these standards will improve Federal financial management in the long term. The Act aims to provide full disclosure of Federal financial data, increase accountability, improve performance and efficiency, establish financial management systems, and build upon existing financial management laws. The Act aims to increase agencies' capability to monitor budget execution by allowing reports comparing resource spending to activity results. SEC. 3. IMPLEMENTATION OF FEDERAL FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT IMPROVEMENTS. Each agency must comply with Federal financial management systems requirements, prioritize funding for implementation, and undergo audits to ensure compliance. When an audit finds noncompliance with financial management system requirements, the report must include details such as the responsible officer, nature of noncompliance, reasons, and recommended remedial actions with timeframes. The Director will determine agency compliance with financial management system requirements based on audited financial statements, agency comments, and other relevant information within 90 days of receiving the agency-wide report. The Director will assess agency compliance with financial management system requirements within 90 days of receiving an agency-wide audited financial statement. If non-compliance is found, the agency must establish a remediation plan in consultation with the Director to bring the financial management systems into compliance within 2 years. The agency must bring its financial management systems into compliance with requirements within 2 years of the Director's determination, unless the agency's systems are deemed deficient, in which case a feasible compliance date must be specified, and an official designated to ensure compliance. The agency can transfer up to 2 percent of available appropriations for financial management system improvements with approval from the Director, but not for items denied funds by Congress. Notification to Congress is required 30 days before any transfer. The Director can authorize transfers of up to 2 percent of agency appropriations for financial management system improvements. If an agency fails to comply within the specified time period, a report must be submitted to Congress detailing the noncompliance. Any financial officer or program manager who knowingly and willfully deviates from requirements may face disciplinary action, suspension, or removal from office. SEC. 4. APPLICATION TO CONGRESS AND THE JUDICIAL BRANCH. The Federal financial management requirements of this Act can be adopted by the Senate, House of Representatives, and the Judicial Conference of the United States. A study and report on achieving compliance with financial management standards must be conducted by the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives by October 1, 1997. The Chief Justice of the United States will conduct a study and submit a report to Congress on achieving compliance with financial management and accounting standards comparable to the requirements of the Act. SEC. 5. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.

The Director must submit an annual report to Congress by March 31 on the Act's implementation. The Comptroller General will report to Congress by October 1 each year on compliance with Act requirements and the adequacy of accounting standards for the Federal Government.

SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. In amendments to title 31, United States Code, agencies' audits are updated, and a financial management status report requirement is revised to include agencies not in compliance with the Federal Financial Management Improvement Act of 1996. Efforts are being made to address noncompliance with the Federal Financial Management Improvement Act of 1996. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. For purposes of this Act, "agency" refers to a department or agency of the United States Government, "Director" means the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, "Federal accounting standards" are accounting principles and standards consistent with title 31, United States Code, and "financial management systems" include financial systems necessary for financial management support. The financial system encompasses automated and manual processes, controls, data, hardware, software, and support personnel for managing financial operations. It includes collecting, processing, maintaining, transmitting, and reporting financial data, supporting financial planning and budgeting, accumulating and reporting costs, and preparing financial statements. The curr_chunk is about an information system that supports financial and nonfinancial functions of the Federal Government or its components. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1996, as per the Senate's approval on August 2, 1996.
